util.sequence

Class Streams

  • java.lang.Object
    • util.sequence.Streams

  • public class Streams
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility methods to use with Stream's. Similar in concept to the Haskell list processing functions but with all the (ridiculous?) limitations of Java. Do not use for heavy duty or parallel computations. You have been warned...

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructor and Description
      Streams()

    • Method Detail

      • cycle

        public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<T> cycle(int times,
                                                   java.util.stream.Stream<T> ts)
        Repeats a finite stream the specified number of times. This is a terminal operation on the input stream.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        times - how many times to repeat the input stream.
        ts - the input stream.
        Returns:
        the stream ts + ts + ... + ts, the given number of times.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any argument is null.

      • inits

        public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<java.util.stream.Stream<T>> inits(java.util.stream.Stream<T> ts)
        Builds the initial segments of the given finite input stream ts. For example, if ts = [1, 2, 3] then init(ts) = [[], [1], [1,2], [1,2,3]]. This is a terminal operation.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        ts - the input stream.
        Returns:
        the initial segments of ts.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any argument is null.

      • zipWith

        public static <X,Y,Z> java.util.stream.Stream<Z> zipWith(java.util.function.BiFunction<X,Y,Z> f,
                                                         java.util.stream.Stream<X> xs,
                                                         java.util.stream.Stream<Y> ys)
        Maps the function f over the list of pairs (x0, y0), (x1, y1), ... , (xm, ym) with xk in xs and yk in ys and where m is the length of the shortest between xs and ys. For example (pseudo code): zipWith((x,y) -> x + y, [a,b], [1,2,3]) = [a1, b2]. This is a terminal operation on the input streams.
        Type Parameters:
        X - any type.
        Y - any type.
        Z - any type.
        Parameters:
        f - the function to map.
        xs - the list providing the left values.
        ys - the list providing the right values.
        Returns:
        the "zipped" list.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any argument is null.

      • zip

        public static <X,Y> java.util.stream.Stream<Pair<X,Y>> zip(java.util.stream.Stream<X> xs,
                                                           java.util.stream.Stream<Y> ys)
        Pairs up the elements of two lists up to the length of the shortest of the two. For example (pseudo code): zip([a,b], [1,2,3]) = [(a, 1), (b, 2)]. This is a terminal operation on the input streams.
        Type Parameters:
        X - any type.
        Y - any type.
        Parameters:
        xs - the list providing the left values.
        ys - the list providing the right values.
        Returns:
        the "zipped" list.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any argument is null.

      • zipIndex

        public static <X> java.util.stream.Stream<Pair<java.lang.Integer,X>> zipIndex(java.util.stream.Stream<X> xs)
        Indexes the elements of the given finite list, starting from 0. For example (pseudo code): zipIndex([a,b,c]) = [(a, 0), (b, 1), (c, 2)]. This is a terminal operation on the input streams.
        Type Parameters:
        X - any type.
        Parameters:
        xs - the list to index.
        Returns:
        the indexed list.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any argument is null.

      • map

        public static <Y,Z> java.util.stream.Stream<Z> map(java.util.function.BiFunction<java.lang.Integer,Y,Z> f,
                                                   java.util.stream.Stream<Y> ys)
        Applies the function f to each element of the stream. The function f is called with the index (in ys) of the element to map (first argument) and with the element itself (second argument). That is: map(f,[v,w,...]) = [f(0,v),f(1,w),...]. For example (pseudo code) if f(i,x) = i+x then map(f,[1,2,3]) = [1,3,5].
        Type Parameters:
        Y - any type.
        Z - any type.
        Parameters:
        f - turns an index and a Y into a Z.
        ys - the list to map.
        Returns:
        a new list with the mapped elements.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any argument is null.

      • intersperse

        public static <X> java.util.stream.Stream<X> intersperse(java.util.function.Supplier<X> sep,
                                                         java.util.stream.Stream<X> xs)
        Interleaves the elements of the given stream with the specified separator. For example (pseudo code) intersperse(0,[1,2,3]) = [1,0,2,0,3].
        Type Parameters:
        X - any type.
        Parameters:
        sep - the value to put in between stream elements; ideally this should be a new object for each slot.
        xs - the elements to interleave.
        Returns:
        the interleaved list.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any argument is null.

      • pruneNull

        public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<T> pruneNull(java.util.stream.Stream<T> xs)
        Removes all null's from the stream; if the stream itself is null, then the empty stream is returned.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        xs - the stream to cleanse.
        Returns:
        the cleansed stream.

        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        xs - the list to cleanse.
        Returns:
        the cleansed stream.

      • pruneNull

        Removes all null's from the array; if the array itself is null, then the empty stream is returned.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        xs - the array to cleanse.
        Returns:
        the cleansed stream.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the stream's elements collected into a list.

      • asStream

        public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<T> asStream(java.util.List<T> xs)
        Collects the given list's elements into a stream; if the list is null, then the empty stream is returned.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        xs - the list to convert.
        Returns:
        the list's elements collected into a stream.

      • asStream

        public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<T> asStream(java.util.Optional<T> maybeValue)
        Puts an optional value into a stream. If the given value is null or an empty optional, then the empty stream is returned; otherwise a stream containing the optional value.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        maybeValue - the value to convert, possibly null.
        Returns:
        an empty stream or a stream with the optional value as the case may be.

      • emptyIfNull

        public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<T> emptyIfNull(java.util.stream.Stream<T> xs)
        Returns empty if the argument is null, otherwise the argument itself.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        xs - a possibly null reference.
        Returns:
        xs if not null, an empty stream otherwise.

      • concat

        @SafeVarargs
public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<T> concat(java.util.stream.Stream<T>... xs)
        Joins the given streams in encounter order. For example (pseudo code): concat([1, 2], null, [3, 4]) = [1, 2, 3, 4]. Any null stream is replaced with empty.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        xs - the streams to join.
        Returns:
        the joined stream.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the argument array is null.

      • pairUp

        public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<Pair<T,T>> pairUp(java.util.stream.Stream<T> xs)
        Collects the items of the given finite stream into pairs. Items are paired up in encounter order and if there's an odd number of them, the second element of the last pair will be null. For example (pseudo code): pairUp [1, null, 3, 4, 5] = [ (1, null), (3, 4), (5, null)]. (Note that any null input item will be put in the right place, no exception is thrown.)
        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        xs - the input items.
        Returns:
        the input items collected into pairs.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the argument is null.

      • unpair

        public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<T> unpair(java.util.stream.Stream<Pair<T,T>> xs)
        Flattens the given stream of pairs in encounter order. For example (pseudo code): unpair [(1, null), (3, 4), (5, null)] = [1, null, 3, 4, 5, null]. Note that if the stream contains a null Pair, then an exception is thrown. However, any null within a Pair will be put in the right place, no exception is thrown.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any type.
        Parameters:
        xs - the input pairs.
        Returns:
        the flattened stream.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the argument or any of its pair objects is null.
